title: Designing Digital Experiences for Participants in a National Health Research Program
problem:
Medical research has a diversity problem. 90% of the U.S. patient population aren't involved in research and don't want to think about their health — until they have to (Ma et al., Minority Representation in Clinical Trials in the United States, 2021). The *All of Us Research Program* aims to enroll one million participants to deliver the most diverse medical research database. To reach and maintain that number of participants, the program requires design focused on the participant experience. Our team at GoInvo, with experience and expertise in health design for humans and shipping research software, brought this focus to the foreground and tackled a variety of challenges:

 How do we... 
 - Deliver health surveys and health information to participants from all walks of life, in a way all can understand?
 - Craft meaningful returns of value to the participants, to show appreciations and recognition for their contribution?
 - Onboard new participants and help them  understand participation, consent, and data privacy?
 - Show the value of participation to the nation and to the lives of all patients?
solution: GoInvo led product design as part of the Participants Technology Systems Center (PTSC) for the *All of Us* participant portal on behalf of Vibrent Health from 2020 through 2024. GoInvo designers became participants, spoke to participants, and dived deep into the program. We worked across the consortium of stakeholders including all roles from policy experts to researchers to design and launch program initiatives and strategies that meet participants where they are. We collaboratively developed participant journeys, screen content, and UI designs, then worked with the technical teams to see those designs all the way to delivery.
results:
Through program-wide design, UX leadership, guidance, and coordination between research groups, program offices, and technology delivery teams, our team has helped to:

 -  Deliver experiences for participants to contribute more health information through surveys and sharing biosamples.
 - Provide engaging insights to share with participants what the program is learning from their contributions.
 - Make accessible pathways to encourage more participants to join the *All of Us* Research Program. 
 - Reach 700,000+ enrolled participants and growing.
commitment: Team of 2-4 designers over 3 years. I was involved for 2+ years, and led and managed multiple initiatives from concept to delivery.

contentBlocks.text: Overview

The *All of Us Research Program*, run by the National Institutes of Health (NIH), is a nationwide health study that aims to collect health data from a diverse group of 1 million or more people living in the United States. The program aims to run for 10 years or more, providing this diverse dataset longitudinally. Every human is unique, with different genes, lifestyles, and living conditions, and circumstances that change over time. The more researchers can learn about what affects people's health, the better they will be able to drive research that impacts more humans. 

 The program is an ambitious government-funded health research effort with the goal to retain and engage participants long-term. More than a hundred funded partner organizations work together to run the *All of Us Research Program*. GoInvo was brought in as a small task force, working as the design team for the PTSC under Vibrent Health to support the digital experience in the PTSC Participant Portal.

We worked within the *All of Us* online portal, the primary way participants engage with the program. Partners of all roles contributed to the experiences offered on the portal, and our role was to coordinate those contributions and create a cohesive experience for participants.

Participants who join contribute through answering surveys, providing biosamples, sharing electronic health records (EHRs), and more. The program maintains their information and provides de-identified data to researchers. Participants can access the online portal to stay connected with the program and receive results demonstrating the impact of their contributions to the program. PTSC's focus was to provide a digital platform to support participation by delivering surveys, communications, and returns of results. GoInvo facilitated this by focusing on participant's perspectives and needs.
The Process

GoInvo's day-to-day operations varied to adapt to program priorities, encompassing diverse roles that involved design, project management, user experience expertise, product validation (QA), and collaborative engagement with program consortium stakeholders. 

 **Dive deep to understand the program and platform.** 

 - Live the problem (enroll and participate in the program). 
 - See the problem (work directly with participants, researchers, policy, and engineering). 
 - Design shippable solutions (understand and build around program and technical constraints). 
 - Live the solution (embed ourselves across teams). 

 **Live the problem set with an audit of the participant experience.** 
 We conducted a system-wide review of the participant portal and user feedback to better understand the participant experience. We enrolled, becoming official participants in the *All of Us Research Program* and learned first hand what the participant experience is, with an understanding that there are variations across participants.  

  **Get to know the platform (behind the scenes).** 
 Based on our expert review we proposed improvements. The recommendations ranged from user interface enhancements such as styling, consistency of interactions, to content voice, readability, comprehension, information hierarchy and architecture. In the process, we learned that operational, engineering, and policy constraints impose major roadblocks to all sorts of changes, including simple details like button color. The reality of designing for a national research program is that prioritization and scope of work depend upon funding, and we learned how to design and strategize within those constraints. 

 **Repeat for every initiative.** 
 Every new initiative has its own intricacies. Read the protocol, live the related experiences, and check with engineering to get ahead of any expected limitations and considerations. Build an understanding of what you're working with right up front.
Open the prototype to explore the full participant journey.
Results

**Delivered shippable designs for program initiatives.** 
 We worked closely with Vibrent Health's program and technical teams to support design tasks for *All of Us*, allowing us to learn how the teams implement, develop, and maintain the program and portal — what's possible and what's not. Knowing how the portal capabilities and constraints was crucial for designing end-to-end experiences that could be built with the resources and timelines provided.
A few example screens from the portal. On the left is the main dashboard where participants found activities. On the right are examples from a survey on mental health and wellbeing.

**We established design and illustration libraries and created reusable UI components.** 

 We compiled a design library and documented usability patterns based on the preexisting portal. Collaborating with NIH teams, we developed and documented standards for program-wide visuals and illustrations. These reusable components and style guides allowed program teams to design and build prototypes quickly with consistency. As we continued to design new activities for participants in the portal, we adjusted and expanded this guide as needed.

**More than a design team. We became the trusted experts and liaisons, bridging communication between technical, scientific, and program stakeholders.** 

 Because we worked with teams across the entire program, we grew our knowledge of how the program worked that few others had. Our role became more than creating and delivering mockups, we drove conversations through visual and non-visual assets such as requirements docs, diagrams, and specifications.
Over time, as we learned more and gained credibility within the program, we found more opportunities to strategically influence design.

While we did spend time on pixels and prototypes, we helped to glue conversations and pieces of the experience together, and communicate them across different teams, especially in conversations between NIH and Vibrent Health. We became the go-to team to answer questions about how the program or experience worked.

When designing participant experiences, we shared, iterated, and delivered several types of artifacts to comprehensively communicate the proposed solutions to all stakeholders. These included written textual requirements, journey maps, and pixel prototypes.

**Balanced usability, technical, and program needs.** 

 Launching a new activity, like a survey, to the participant portal can take several months and up to a year or more. GoInvo worked closely with the NIH program and UX strategy teams to understand the initiative goals — what we are asking participants to do, and what participants need in return. We then worked together with all stakeholders, including researchers, policy experts, product owners, NIH UX strategists, designers, and engineers, to fine tune the requirements and designed flows, content, and screens. We considered not only the best user experience but also data collection completeness, accessibility to participants who are underrepresented in biomedical research (UBR), implementation timeline and resources, and transparency. 

  Every experience must be approved by the program’s institutional review board (IRB) and NIH leadership members. Once the protocol was approved, implementation began. When ready, we reviewed the experience in a testing environment and reported bugs to be addressed before launching to public participants. Throughout the process, our role as user experience designers was to advocate for participants and support the best experience while balancing usability against program policy and implementation constraints. 

 **Developed strategy for returning personal and program results.** 

 The program aims to provide meaningful value to participants by returning results based on their provided biosamples and completed surveys. Through interviews and feedback, we found that participants needed more context and substance than the program was providing. This called for creative solutions to deliver meaning and context within policy and technical limitations. We developed and validated with participants content guidelines, templates, and a process to help teams deliver results that participants will find valuable. Participants also told us they wanted to hear about program success. So we designed and saw through the launch a new 'Insights' page delivering news and announcements about scientific discoveries across the consortium.

We designed several ways to give value back to the participants, such as templates for returning interpretive results with context and an Insights page sharing success stories and discoveries made possible by *All of Us* data.

### Proposed program design 

 Our team designed many concepts, some of which didn't make it into the experience. We wanted to show what the program *could* be capable of and give stakeholders ideas to share and grow within the program. Some of these proposals: 

 - Deliver a focused home page that highlights the next activity for the participant to complete. 
 - Provide more research context throughout the participant journey, including personalizing research returns on the data they provided. 
 - Offer forms that are clearer and faster to complete. 
 - Track biosample kits from collection to Biobank and DNA processing. 
 - Driving participation through tangible rewards. 
 - Engage participants through low effort activities that collect participant life data for long-term collection 
 - A new information architecture and workflow that directs participants to the  next activity and brings focus to new relevant information and opportunities.
Takeaways

### The future of medical research engages participants 

 If medical research programs aim to prioritize participant enrollment and retention, a digital experience for participants should:

 - Provide participants with more transparency and agency around the data they provide for research. 
 -  Acknowledge participant contribution with choice-focused return of value framework to encourage participation and involvement in the program community. 
 -  Provide participants with more connections to research using program data. 
 -   Personalize the participant journey and research returns based on the data they provide. 
 -  Support participant decision-making for difficult topics while reducing condescension or coercion in messaging. 
 -  Prioritize optimal data collection for ease of use, readability, and comprehension, which will also support providing quality, clean data for researchers to use. 

 ### National research projects pose unique challenges 

 **Participants come from diverse backgrounds and have different needs.** Understanding participants is critical to designing for a flexible program that addresses varied circumstances and meets participants where they are. 

 **Different teams have different backgrounds, priorities, and responsibilities.** Program goals, technical constraints, policy requirements, and participant needs are not always aligned. As designers, we must lean on design approaches and champion their impact on the user experience. We needed to drive conversations by showing designs to support informed decision-making with the program that highlight what is best for the participant. And sometimes, we must be ready to swiftly develop alternative solutions across barriers.

 **Program decisions are sometimes made prematurely, without fully considering implementation and user experience consequences.** We learned to push our way into projects earlier and get involved with the smaller decision-making teams. We advocated for the participant user experience and crafted flexible solutions that accommodate less-than-ideal situations.

 **Different teams and situations call for different methods of design and communication.** Visual designs couldn't support all conversations. It's important to identify the right kind of delivery and level of detail, whether documentation, specs, requirements, or a bullet list.
Results

Impacting 750k registered participants through program-wide design, UX leadership, guidance, and coordination between research groups and program offices, our team at GoInvo helped to: 

 -  Deliver new and improved experiences for participants to contribute health data through surveys, digital health connections, and biosample donation. 
 -  Provide engaging insights to share with participants what the program is learning from their contributions. 
 -   Guide design and recommend during initiative conception and requirements. 
 -  Developed a visual asset and illustration library and standard that is used across the program for digital and print materials. 
 - Provide support on implementation and development.
